deity.name: Solos
deity.title: The Sunlord
deity.symbol: A bursting sun caught in the jaws of a bear
entries: Solos acts as the chief of the gods. Followers of Solos are often so enamored of his brilliance that they reduce the other deities to mere servants of Solos. Many a war has been waged in the name of Solos and his justice.

deity.name: Lunéya
deity.title: The Seamstress of Stars
deity.symbol: A crescent moon with a shooting star
entries: Lunéya is thought by many to be the progenitor of magic for mortals. Her magic is not granted but earned, and even wizards may say a prayer to Lunéya before attempting a particularly difficult piece of magic.

deity.name: Vlasta
deity.title: Allmother
deity.symbol: A campfire inside a stone keep
entries: Vlasta is a force of goodness, with a fatal flaw. Vlasta cannot abide any wavering loyalty to her, and she can be vain. Of all the gods, she is most likely to have pity on the plight of a mortal. Vlasta is often viewed as the patron of healers and midwives.

deity.name: Sellen
deity.title: The Voice in the Dark
deity.symbol: A raven skull, one eye socket is punched in
entries: Sellen is feared by mortals, but her presence is often less frightening and more calming. Sellen and Vlasta have a strained relationship, as Vlasta’s domain is birth and Sellen’s is death. Elves often worship Sellen, as they concern themselves much with their fate, and expect to not face the death of mortal beings.

deity.name: Occelita
deity.title: The Verdant Huntress
entries: Occelita is feisty and spirited, she values skill in battle and ferocity above wisdom. In ancient days Occelita often accepted mortals to hunt with her, but as the wild places have been diminished she has withdrawn her favor from mortal beings.

deity.name: Kuvira
deity.title: Windcaller
entries: Kuvira is often viewed as humorless, because she has no mercy for those who violate her travel blessing. However, when the day’s journey is over Kuvira’s gift of songs can provide a ward from the terrors of the night and the hardships of the road. Bards often claim Kuvira as a patron.

deity.name: Torval
deity.title: Runecarver
entries: Torval is a god of creation, and is considered the patron god of craftsmen and artificers. Often depicted as a jovial bearded man, it is uncommon for Torval to be viewed with animosity.

deity.name: Displasí
deity.title: The Many-Faced god
deity.symbol: A mask divided into quadrants, each expresses a partial emotion
entries: Displasí rarely appears the same way twice, he is difficult to read and holds a grudge if he feels wronged. Displasí’s true nature is obscured beyond the comprehension of most mortals, even his name is rarely uttered.

deity.name: Thum
deity.title: Devourer of the Deep
entries: Thum can be surly and solitary, but he understands the lifeblood of the earth better than anyone. Thum’s knowledge of blood, water, and war was essential to the creation of the first orcs. Thum is often invoked as a danger to sailors and a bringer of wrath and ruin.

deity.name: Serris
deity.title: Mistress of Thorns
deity.symbol: A snake coiled around a scroll
entries: Serris is a goddess of her word, and often promises power in exchange for service. Serris is the historic patron of the yuan-ti, but many believe that she will grant power to the dying in exchange for eternal servitude.

trait.name: Petrifying Gaze
entries: If a creature starts its turn within 15 feet of the basilisk and the two of them can see each other, the basilisk can force the creature to make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw if the basilisk isn't {@condition incapacitated}. On a failed save, the creature magically begins to turn to stone and is {@condition restrained}. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature is {@condition petrified} until freed by the  {@spell greater restoration} spell or other magic.

A creature that isn't {@quickref Surprise|PHB|3|0|surprised} can avert its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If it does so, it can't see the basilisk until the start of its next turn, when it can avert its eyes again. If it looks at the basilisk in the meantime, it must immediately make the save.
If the basilisk sees its reflection within 30 feet of it in bright light, it mistakes itself for a rival and targets itself with its gaze.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) acid  damage.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the pachycephalosaurus moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a ram attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 5 ({@damage 2d4}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Sure-Footed
entries: The pachycephalosaurus has advantage on Strength and Dexterity saving throws made against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.
This bipedal dinosaur is a herbivore that can be deadly if provoked. Its bony crest can be used to deal crushing blows if enough momentum is built up.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dilophosaurus makes one Bite or Poison Saliva attack and two Claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage, plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Poison Saliva {@recharge 5}
entries: The dilophosaurus spits a glob of venom at a point it can see within 30 feet of it. Each creature within 5 feet of that point must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
This bipedal carnivore is known for spitting venom at its prey and then moving close to strike the final blow.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The carnotaurus makes three attacks: two with its bite and one with its horns.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage. If the target is a Small or smaller creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the carnotaurus can't bite another target.

action.name: Horns
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d10 + 5}) piercing damage.

This carnivore is known for its distinctive horns and lighter build, making carnotaurus smaller than its larger tyrannosaur cousins. Carnotaurus has less jaw strength than a tyrannosaur, but makes up for its raw power with its speed.

entries.name: Dinosaurs
entries: Dinosaurs, or behemoths, are among the oldest reptiles in the world. Predatory dinosaurs are savage, territorial hunters. Herbivorous dinosaurs are less aggressive, but they might attack to defend their young, or if startled or harassed.

Dinosaurs come in many sizes and shapes. Larger varieties often have drab coloration, while smaller dinosaurs have colorful markings akin to birds. Dinosaurs roam rugged and isolated areas that humanoids seldom visit, including remote mountain valleys, inaccessible plateaus, tropical islands, and deep fens.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The clam can breathe air and water.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The clam makes one Bite and one Claw attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition restrained} (escape {@dc 13}).

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) slashing damage. The clam can make Claw attacks against creatures that are {@condition restrained} in its shell.

These horrifying clams have multiple legs attached to the hinge of their shell that they use to chase down their prey. Inside the shell, their prey is slowly digested, and elements that cannot be absorbed as nutrients are spat out.
Much like their smaller cousins, these giant clams produce proportionately large {@item pearl||pearls} that are worth 150 gold pieces to the right seller.

vulnerable.note: damage to the clam's inner flesh

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The starfish can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Chameleon Skin
entries: The starfish has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage, plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage.

monster.name: Mutant Bear

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The mutant bear has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Mimicry
entries: The mutant bear can mimic animal sounds and humanoid voices. A creature that hears the sounds can tell they are imitations with a successful {@dc 14} Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check.

trait.name: Quid Edis Fies
entries: If the mutant bear consumes the flesh of a creature, it absorbs one of that creature's abilities or physical traits. The mutant bear's bite attack triggers this ability.
The traits are chosen at random, and can conflict with the mutant bear's existing physiology. If abilities or physical traits are in conflict, the bear suffers {@damage 1d6} necrotic damage.
If the mutant bear has eaten enough of a creature to gain all of its abilities, it can gain a skill proficiency or increase an ability score.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The mutant bear makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage. On a successful hit, the mutant bear's {@b {@i Quid Edis Fies}} ability activates.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.
This mutated bear uses its ability to mimic sounds to lure its prey, making guttural sounds of distress or phrases such as "help me" in a haunting, coarse imitation of speech.

entries.name: Twisted Beyond Belief
entries: Originally a normal black bear, this creature has been mutated into a twisted form of life. The face of the mutant bear has withered away, revealing the bare bone of its snout and mouth. The side of the bear's face has grown a human skull. Grown larger than its typical species, the mutant bear is more resilient to damage and has integrated part of the intelligence of a human it killed into its form.
That sounds like Cassie! Cassie, I'm coming!
entries.by: Last words of Lyla Johannson, human cartographer

languages: the language of a humanoid the mutant bear has killed

variant.name: Orc-Fed Mutant Bear
entries: A mutant bear that has consumed {@creature orc|MM|orcs} may have the following traits:
{@b {@i Relentless Endurance (1/day).}} When the mutant bear is reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, it instead drops to 1 hit point instead.
{@b {@i Aggressive.}} As a bonus action, the mutant bear can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.
{@b {@i Ability Score Increase.}} The mutant bear's Strength score or Constitution score increase by 2.

variant.name: Bear-Owl
entries: A mutant bear that has consumed a {@creature giant owl} may have the following traits:
{@b {@i Wings.}} The mutant bear sprouts two wings from its back, granting it a fly speed of 60 ft.
{@b {@i Flyby.}} The mutant bear doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.
{@b {@i Keen Perception.}} The mutant bear now makes all Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) with advantage. Additionally, the mutant bear's {@sense darkvision} now extends to 120 ft.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Glimmer's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 12}). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring only her pixie dust as a component:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Glimmer has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Superior Invisibility
entries: Glimmer magically turns {@condition invisible} until her {@status concentration} ends (as if {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell). Any equipment Glimmer wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with her.
Standing barely a foot tall, pixies resemble diminutive elves with gossamer wings like those of dragonflies or butterflies, bright as the clear dawn and as luminous as the full moonrise.

Curious as cats and shy as deer, pixies go where they please. They like to spy on other creatures and can barely contain their excitement around them. The urge to introduce themselves and strike up a friendship is almost overwhelming; only a pixie's fear of being captured or attacked stays its hand. Those who wander through a pixie's glade might never see the creatures, yet hear the occasional giggle, gasp, or sigh.

Pixies array themselves like princes and princesses of the fey, wearing flowing gowns and doublets of silk that sparkle like moonlight on a pond. Some dress in acorns, leaves, bark, and the pelts of tiny woodland beasts. They take great pride in their regalia and beam with joy when they are complimented on their ensembles.

entries.name: Magical Faerie Folk
entries: With their innate power of invisibility, pixies rarely appear unless they wish to be seen. In the Feywild and on the Material Plane, pixies etch patterns of frost on winter ponds and rouse the buds in springtime. They cause flowers to sparkle with summer dew, and color the leaves with the blazing hues of autumn.

entries.name: Pixie Dust
entries: When pixies fly visibly, a shower of sparkling dust follows in their wake like the glittering tail of a shooting star. A mere sprinkle of pixie dust is said to be able to grant the power of flight, confuse a creature hopelessly, or send foes into a magical slumber.
Only pixies can use their dust to its full potential, but these fey are constantly sought out by mages and monsters seeking to study or master their power.

entries.name: Tiny Tricksters
entries: While the arrival of visitors piques their curiosity, pixies are too shy to reveal themselves at first. They study the visitors from afar to gauge their temperament or play harmless tricks on them to measure their reactions. For example, pixies might tie a dwarf's boots together, create illusions of strange creatures or treasures, or use dancing lights to lead interlopers astray. If the visitors respond with hostility, the pixies give them a wide berth. If the visitors are good natured, the pixies are likely to be emboldened and more friendly. The fey might even emerge and offer to guide their "guests" along a safe route or invite them to a tiny yet satisfying feast prepared in their honor.

entries.name: Opposed to Violence
entries: Unlike their fey cousins, the sprites, pixies abhor weapons and would sooner flee than get into a physical altercation with any enemy.
Petal gowns and acorn caps are so last summer!

action.name: Lance
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 piercing damage.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 40/160 ft., one target. {@h}1 piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. If its saving throw result is 5 or lower, the {@condition poisoned} target falls {@condition unconscious} for the same duration, or until it takes damage or another creature takes an action to shake it awake.

action.name: Heart Sight
entries: The sprite touches a creature and magically knows the creature's current emotional state. If the target fails a {@dc 10} Charisma saving throw, the sprite also knows the creature's alignment. Celestials, fiends, and undead automatically fail the saving throw.

action.name: Invisibility
entries: The sprite magically turns {@condition invisible} until it attacks or casts a spell, or until its {@status concentration} ends (as if {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell). Any equipment the sprite wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with it.

In secret groves and shaded glens, tiny sprites with dragonfly wings flutter. For all their fey splendor, however, sprites lack warmth and compassion. They are aggressive and hardy warriors, taking severe measures to ward strangers away from their homes. Interlopers that come too close have their moral character judged, then are put to sleep or frightened off.

entries.name: Forest Protectors
entries: Sprites build little villages in the boughs of trees and willing treants, in verdant glades brightened by moss, wild flowers, and toadstools. Wild nature thrives, and the sprites allow no trespassers. When intruders are spotted, the sprites lead them astray with ominous rustling from the bushes and distant snapping twigs. Creatures foolish enough to persist in intruding on a sprite's territory are stung with poisoned arrows and lulled into a senseless sleep. While they slumber, the sprites make good their escape, retreating to an even more secluded area of the forest.

entries.name: Heart Seers
entries: Sprites can sense whether a creature is good or evil by the sound and feeling of its beating heart. Weighing the balance of a creature's past actions, a sprite can tell whether its heart beats rapidly in love or flags in sorrow, or whether it is darkened by hate or greed. The sprite's power to perceive the heart always shows the truth, because the heart can't lie.

entries.name: Poison Brewers
entries: In their forest domains, sprites brew toxins, unguents, antidotes, and poisons, including the sleep poison with which they coat their arrows. They venture far into the woods to harvest rare flowers, mosses, and fungi, sometimes crossing dangerous territory to do so. If desperate, sprites even steal their ingredients from the gardens of hags.

entries.name: Good-Hearted
entries: Because they are judges of the heart and favor good creatures, sprites oppose the will of evil fey and pledge to thwart evil archfey at every turn. If they encounter adventurers on a quest to rid their forest of an evil fey creature or goblinoid menace, they will pledge their support and even come to their aid when the adventurers least expect it.

Unlike pixies, sprites rarely indulge in frivolous merriment and fun. They are firm warriors, protectors, and judges, and their stern bent causes other fey to consider them overly dour and serious. However, fey that respect the sprites' territory find them staunch allies in times of trouble.

The tree had a wee village nestled in its boughs, I swear. Next thing I knew, I was lyin' face-down in the dirt. My head was full of stars. An' when I stood up an' looked around, both the tree an' the wee village were gone.

trait.name: Relentless Endurance
entries: Once per long rest, when Saru is reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, she can drop to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Saru makes one Greataxe and one Light Hammer attack

action.name: Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d12 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Light Hammer
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.
Orcs are savage raiders and pillagers with stooped postures, low foreheads, and piggish faces with prominent lower canines that resemble tusks.

entries.name: Gruumsh One-Eye
entries: Orcs worship Gruumsh, the mightiest of the orc deities and their creator. The orcs believe that in ancient days, the gods gathered to divide the world among their followers. When Gruumsh claimed the mountains, he learned they had been taken by the dwarves. He laid claim to the forests, but those had been settled by the elves. Each place that Gruumsh wanted had already been claimed. The other gods laughed at Gruumsh, but he responded with a furious bellow. Grasping his mighty spear, he laid waste to the mountains, set the forests aflame, and carved great furrows in the fields. Such was the role of the orcs, he proclaimed, to take and destroy all that the other races would deny them. To this day, the orcs wage an endless war on humans, elves, dwarves, and other folk.

Orcs hold a particular hatred for elves. The elven god Corellon Larethian half-blinded Gruumsh with a well-placed arrow to the orc god's eye. Since then, the orcs have taken particular joy in slaughtering elves. Turning his injury into a baleful gift, Gruumsh grants divine might to any champion who willingly plucks out one of its eyes in his honor.

entries.name: Tribes like Plagues
entries: Orcs gather in tribes that exert their dominance and satisfy their bloodlust by plundering villages, devouring or driving off roaming herds, and slaying any humanoids that stand against them. After savaging a settlement, orcs pick it clean of wealth and items usable in their own lands. They set the remains of villages and camps ablaze, then retreat whence they came, their bloodlust satisfied.

entries.name: Ranging Scavengers
entries: Their lust for slaughter demands that orcs dwell always within striking distance of new targets. As such, they seldom settle permanently, instead converting ruins, cavern complexes, and defeated foes' villages into fortified camps and strongholds. Orcs build only for defense, making no innovation or improvement to their lairs beyond mounting the severed body parts of their victims on spiked stockade walls or pikes jutting up from moats and trenches.

When an existing territory is depleted of food, an orc tribe divides into roving bands that scout for choice hunting grounds. When each party returns, it brings back trophies and news of targets ripe for attack, the richest of which is chosen. The tribe then sets out en masse to carve a bloody path to its new territory.
On rare occasions, a tribe's leader chooses to hold onto a particularly defensible lair for decades. The orcs of such a tribe must range far across the countryside to sate their appetites.

entries.name: Leadership and Might
entries: Orc tribes are mostly patriarchal, flaunting such vivid or grotesque titles as Many-Arrows, Screaming Eye, and Elf Ripper. Occasionally, a powerful war chief unites scattered orc tribes into a single rampaging horde, which runs roughshod over other orc tribes and humanoid settlements from a position of overwhelming strength.

Strength and power are the greatest of orcish virtues, and orcs embrace all manner of mighty creatures in their tribes. Rejecting notions of racial purity, they proudly welcome ogres, trolls, half-orcs, and orogs into their ranks. As well, orcs respect and fear the size and power of evil giants, and often serve them as guards and soldiers.

entries.name: Orc Crossbreeds
entries: Luthic, the orc goddess of fertility and wife of Gruumsh, demands that orcs procreate often and indiscriminately so that orc hordes swell generation after generation. The orcs' drive to reproduce runs stronger than any other humanoid race, and they readily crossbreed with other races. When an orc procreates with a non-orc humanoid of similar size and stature (such as a human or a dwarf), the resulting child is either an orc or a half-orc. When an orc produces young with an ogre, the child is a half-ogre of intimidating strength and brutish features called an ogrillon.

action.name: Pitchfork
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage.
Commoners include peasants, serfs, slaves, servants, pilgrims, merchants, artisans, and hermits.

trait.name: Halfling Nimbleness
entries: Hamlow can move through the space of any creature that is of a size larger than his.

trait.name: Lucky
entries: When Hamlow rolls a 1 on an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, he can reroll the die and must use the new roll.

trait.name: Brave
entries: Hamlow has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

monster.name: Penguin with Swords Strapped to Its Feet

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The penguin can hold its breath for 10 minutes.

trait.name: Makeshift Ice Skates
entries: The penguin ignores difficult terrain created by frozen surfaces, and instead doubles its movement speed.

trait.name: Fancy Footwork
entries: Once per turn, if the penguin hits with a melee attack against a creature, that creature can't make opportunity attacks against the penguin for the rest of its turn.

action.name: Pirouette Slice
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage.

Only a true mad genius would combine the depraved mind of a penguin with the cruel blades of a sword. This horrifying pairing barely qualifies as a beast, and all who behold the fruits of its rampage would surely declare it an abomination against nature.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Gor is a 5th-level spellcaster. Gor's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). Gor has the following paladin spells prepared:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Gor attacks twice with his greatsword, he can replace one greatsword attack with a breath weapon attack.

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Acid Breath Weapon (3/Day)
entries: Gor exhales acid in a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking 11 ({@damage 2d10}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Divine Smite
entries: When Gor hits a creature with a melee weapon attack, he can expend one spell slot to deal radiant damage to the target, in addition to the weapon's damage. The extra damage is {@dice 2d8} for a 1st-level spell slot, plus {@dice 1d8} for each spell level higher than 1st, to a maximum of {@dice 5d8}. The damage increases by {@dice 1d8} if the target is an undead or a fiend, to a maximum of {@dice 6d8}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Ugaro has been blessed by {@deity Thum|Nírmun|NírmunMiscellany} with some spells. His spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 11}, {@hit 3} to hit with spell attacks). Ugaro has the following cleric spells prepared:

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h} 6 ({@dice 1d6 + 3} piercing damage, or 7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

One of the strongest warriors of the Rustnail Orcs, Ugaro is a devout follower of Thum, and has been blessed with blood magics that strengthen others and give him foresight into the best course of action to take. Ugaro opposes a return to the rule of the Wild Mage, but is hesitant to speak without knowing the mind of Grist first. Ugaro is fierce, but fair.

reaction.name: Martial Role - Defender
entries: Ugaro can use his reaction to impose disadvantage on the attack roll of a creature within 5 feet of him whose target isn't Ugaro, provided Ugaro can see the attacker.

bonus.name: Second Wind (1/rest)
entries: Ugaro can use a bonus action on his turn to regain hit points equal to {@dice 1d10} + his level in this class. Once he uses this feature, he must finish a short or long rest before he can use it again.

bonus.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, Ugaro can move up to his speed toward a hostile creature that he can see.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the orc can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

action.name: Maul
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or suffer an additional {@damage 1d4} piercing damage.
Orcs are savage raiders and pillagers with stooped postures, low foreheads, and piggish faces with prominent lower canines that resemble tusks.

entries.name: Gruumsh One-Eye
entries: Orcs worship Gruumsh, the mightiest of the orc deities and their creator. The orcs believe that in ancient days, the gods gathered to divide the world among their followers. When Gruumsh claimed the mountains, he learned they had been taken by the dwarves. He laid claim to the forests, but those had been settled by the elves. Each place that Gruumsh wanted had already been claimed. The other gods laughed at Gruumsh, but he responded with a furious bellow. Grasping his mighty spear, he laid waste to the mountains, set the forests aflame, and carved great furrows in the fields. Such was the role of the orcs, he proclaimed, to take and destroy all that the other races would deny them. To this day, the orcs wage an endless war on humans, elves, dwarves, and other folk.

Orcs hold a particular hatred for elves. The elven god Corellon Larethian half-blinded Gruumsh with a well-placed arrow to the orc god's eye. Since then, the orcs have taken particular joy in slaughtering elves. Turning his injury into a baleful gift, Gruumsh grants divine might to any champion who willingly plucks out one of its eyes in his honor.

entries.name: Tribes like Plagues
entries: Orcs gather in tribes that exert their dominance and satisfy their bloodlust by plundering villages, devouring or driving off roaming herds, and slaying any humanoids that stand against them. After savaging a settlement, orcs pick it clean of wealth and items usable in their own lands. They set the remains of villages and camps ablaze, then retreat whence they came, their bloodlust satisfied.

entries.name: Ranging Scavengers
entries: Their lust for slaughter demands that orcs dwell always within striking distance of new targets. As such, they seldom settle permanently, instead converting ruins, cavern complexes, and defeated foes' villages into fortified camps and strongholds. Orcs build only for defense, making no innovation or improvement to their lairs beyond mounting the severed body parts of their victims on spiked stockade walls or pikes jutting up from moats and trenches.

When an existing territory is depleted of food, an orc tribe divides into roving bands that scout for choice hunting grounds. When each party returns, it brings back trophies and news of targets ripe for attack, the richest of which is chosen. The tribe then sets out en masse to carve a bloody path to its new territory.
On rare occasions, a tribe's leader chooses to hold onto a particularly defensible lair for decades. The orcs of such a tribe must range far across the countryside to sate their appetites.

entries.name: Leadership and Might
entries: Orc tribes are mostly patriarchal, flaunting such vivid or grotesque titles as Many-Arrows, Screaming Eye, and Elf Ripper. Occasionally, a powerful war chief unites scattered orc tribes into a single rampaging horde, which runs roughshod over other orc tribes and humanoid settlements from a position of overwhelming strength.

Strength and power are the greatest of orcish virtues, and orcs embrace all manner of mighty creatures in their tribes. Rejecting notions of racial purity, they proudly welcome ogres, trolls, half-orcs, and orogs into their ranks. As well, orcs respect and fear the size and power of evil giants, and often serve them as guards and soldiers.

entries.name: Orc Crossbreeds
entries: Luthic, the orc goddess of fertility and wife of Gruumsh, demands that orcs procreate often and indiscriminately so that orc hordes swell generation after generation. The orcs' drive to reproduce runs stronger than any other humanoid race, and they readily crossbreed with other races. When an orc procreates with a non-orc humanoid of similar size and stature (such as a human or a dwarf), the resulting child is either an orc or a half-orc. When an orc produces young with an ogre, the child is a half-ogre of intimidating strength and brutish features called an ogrillon.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the allosaurus moves at least 30 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the allosaurus can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) slashing damage.
The allosaurus is a predator possessing great size, strength, and speed. It can run down almost any prey over open ground, pouncing to pull creatures down with its wicked claws.

entries.name: Dinosaurs
entries: Dinosaurs, or behemoths, are among the oldest reptiles in the world. Predatory dinosaurs are savage, territorial hunters. Herbivorous dinosaurs are less aggressive, but they might attack to defend their young, or if startled or harassed.

Dinosaurs come in many sizes and shapes. Larger varieties often have drab coloration, while smaller dinosaurs have colorful markings akin to birds. Dinosaurs roam rugged and isolated areas that humanoids seldom visit, including remote mountain valleys, inaccessible plateaus, tropical islands, and deep fens.

bonus.name: Radiant Soul (1/day)
entries: Two luminous, spectral wings sprout from the allosaurus' back temporarily. For 1 minute, it has a flying speed equal to its walking speed, and once on each of its turns, it can deal extra radiant damage to one target when the allosaurus deals damage to it with an attack. The extra damage equals its proficiency bonus (2).

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Wild Mage casts one of the following spells, using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 15}):

trait.name: Transmuter's Stone
entries: The Wild Mage carries a magic stone he crafted. The stone grants him one of the following benefits while bearing the stone; the Wild Mage chooses the benefit at the end of each long rest:

items.name: Darkvision
items.entry: The Wild Mage has {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet.

items.name: Resilience
items.entry: The Wild Mage has proficiency in Constitution saving throws.

items.name: Resistance
items.entry: Resistance. The Wild Mage has resistance to acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage (transmuter's choice whenever choosing this benefit).

items.name: Speed
items.entry: The Wild Mage's walking speed is increased by 10 feet.

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: Wyndham the Wild is attuned to a {@item Dead Man's Trigger|NírmunMiscellany}, set to activate a teleport circle underneath his zoo.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Wild Mage makes three Arcane Burst attacks.

action.name: Arcane Burst
entries: {@atk ms,rs} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 120 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d10 + 3}) acid damage.

bonus.name: Transmute {@recharge 4}
entries: The Wild Mage casts {@spell alter self} or changes the benefit of Transmuter's Stone if bearing the stone.
Transmuters are masters at transforming physical forms. They typically view magical transmutation as a path to riches, enlightenment, or apotheosis.

entries.name: Wizards
entries: Wizards pursue magical power through the study of arcane texts. Some travel the world searching for esoteric tomes while others train lesser wizards or collaborate with colleagues to create new spells.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The gnome's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 11}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Gnome Cunning
entries: The gnome has advantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws against magic.

trait.name: Shapechanger (Mimic)
entries: Pip can use its action to polymorph into an object or back into its true, amorphous form. Its statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Grappler
entries: Pip has advantage on attack rolls against any creature {@condition grappled} by it.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage, plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) acid damage.

Deep gnomes, or svirfneblin, live far below the world's surface in twisting warrens and sculpted caverns. They survive by virtue of their stealth, cleverness, and tenacity. Their gray skin allows them to blend in with surrounding stonework. They are also surprisingly heavy and strong for their size. An average adult weighs 100 to 120 pounds and stands 3 feet tall.

A typical svirfneblin enclave contains several hundred deep gnomes and is strongly fortified. Secret tunnels lead to and from the settlement, and the deep gnomes use these as evacuation routes when the enclave comes under attack.

entries.name: Established Gender Roles
entries: Male svirfneblin are bald, while females have stringy gray hair. Traditionally, females run the enclaves while males scour the outskirts in search of enemies and deposits of precious gemstones.

entries.name: Gemstone Harvesters
entries: Svirfneblin cherish fine gemstones, especially rubies, which they harvest from mines deep in the Underdark. The hunt for gems often brings them into conflict with beholders, drow, kuo-toa, duergar, and mind flayers. Of all their natural enemies, deep gnomes fear and despise the murderous, demon worshiping drow the most.

entries.name: Earth Friends
entries: Deep gnomes are often encountered in the company of creatures from the Elemental Plane of Earth. Some svirfneblin can summon such creatures. Earth creatures guard svirfneblin settlements, especially xorn enticed to service with the promise of gems to feed on.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dilophosaurus makes one Bite or Poison Saliva attack and two Claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage, plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) fire damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Fire Glob {@recharge 5}
entries: The dilophosaurus spits a glob of burning liquid at a point it can see within 30 feet of it. Each creature within 5 feet of that point must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
This bipedal carnivore was modified by the Wild Mage to spit globs of flaming liquid. The dilophosaurus subsequently developed an immunity to the fire that they spew forth.

monster.name: Goblin Skeleton
languages: understands all languages it spoke in life but can't speak

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

Skeletons arise when animated by dark magic. They heed the summons of spellcasters who call them from their stony tombs and ancient battlefields, or rise of their own accord in places saturated with death and loss, awakened by stirrings of necromantic energy or the presence of corrupting evil.

entries.name: Animated Dead
entries: Whatever sinister force awakens a skeleton infuses its bones with a dark vitality, adhering joint to joint and reassembling dismantled limbs. This energy motivates a skeleton to move and think in a rudimentary fashion, though only as a pale imitation of the way it behaved in life. An animated skeleton retains no connection to its past, although resurrecting a skeleton restores it body and soul, banishing the hateful undead spirit that empowers it.

While most skeletons are the animated remains of dead humans and other humanoids, skeletal undead can be created from the bones of other creatures besides humanoids, giving rise to a host of terrifying and unique forms.

entries.name: Obedient Servants
entries: Skeletons raised by spell are bound to the will of their creator. They follow orders to the letter, never questioning the tasks their masters give them, regardless of the consequences. Because of their literal interpretation of commands and unwavering obedience, skeletons adapt poorly to changing circumstances. They can't read, speak, emote, or communicate in any way except to nod, shake their heads, or point. Still, skeletons are able to accomplish a variety of relatively complex tasks.

A skeleton can fight with weapons and wear armor, can load and fire a catapult or trebuchet, scale a siege ladder, form a shield wall, or dump boiling oil. However, it must receive careful instructions explaining how such tasks are accomplished.

Although they lack the intellect they possessed in life, skeletons aren't mindless. Rather than break its limbs attempting to batter its way through an iron door, a skeleton tries the handle first. If that doesn't work, it searches for another way through or around the obstacle.

entries.name: Habitual Behaviors
entries: Independent skeletons temporarily or permanently free of a master's control sometimes pantomime actions from their past lives, their bones echoing the rote behaviors of their former living selves. The skeleton of a miner might lift a pick and start chipping away at stone walls. The skeleton of a guard might strike up a post at a random doorway. The skeleton of a dragon might lie down on a pile of treasure, while the skeleton of a horse crops grass it can't eat. Left alone in a ballroom, the skeletons of nobles might continue an eternally unfinished dance.

When skeletons encounter living creatures, the necromantic energy that drives them compels them to kill unless they are commanded by their masters to refrain from doing so. They attack without mercy and fight until destroyed, for skeletons possess little sense of self and even less sense of self-preservation.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A skeleton doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Nimble Escape
entries: The goblin skeleton can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide} action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

action.name: Spellcasting
entries: The necromancer casts one of the following spells, using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks):
At Will: {@spell dancing lights}, {@spell infestation|XGE}, {@spell toll the dead|XGE}
2/day: {@spell inflict wounds}
1/day: {@spell false life} (as a 3rd-level spell), the goblin gains 16 ({@dice 14 + 1d4}) temporary hit points

action.name: Staff
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage, or 6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands.

bonus.name: Cast Sanctuary (2/day)
entries: The necromancer casts {@spell sanctuary} targeting themself. The necromancer cannot cast another leveled spell on the same turn that they cast {@spell sanctuary}.

trait.name: Nimble Escape
entries: The goblin necromancer can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide} action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The flying skull makes one Bite attack and one Bash attack

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Bash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.
Floating, grinning, biting and bonking are the principle activities left to a skeleton with no surviving body. How does it float? Pure spite.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny limb. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

trait.name: Unusual Nature
entries: The swarm doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The swarm makes one Snap, Crackle, Pop attack and one Gnawing Teeth attack.

action.name: Snap, Crackle, Pop
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the swarm's space. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, or 10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer.

action.name: Gnawing Teeth
entries: {@atk ms} reach 0 ft., all creatures in the swarm's space. All creatures in the swarm's space must succeed on a {@dc 12} Strength saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage, be {@condition restrained}. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, taking 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage on a failed save. The creature is freed if it succeeds on this saving throw, the swarm moves out of the creature's space, or the swarm dies.

Among the undead, a lone zombie ranks far from the most menacing. The horror of the shambling dead lies not in their individual menace, though, but their numbers, their persistence, and their disregard for their own well-being. A throng of zombies will douse a forest fire with their own ashes or march into a dragon's maw until the monster chokes. In the course of their relentless marches, zombies might suffer all manner of trauma, potentially reducing them to masses of crawling limbs, infecting them with terrible diseases (see zombie plague spreader), or crushing an entire horde into a single, rotting titan (see zombie clot).

entries.name: Zombie Apocalypses
entries: Among the types of horror adventures detailed in {@book chapter 2|VRGR|2}, tales of uncontrolled zombie outbreaks orbit the {@book dark fantasy|VRGR|2|Dark Fantasy} and {@book disaster horror|VRGR|2|Disaster Horror} genres. The horror of these adventures focuses not on the terror of a single zombie, but of countless individual threats overwhelming society. When creating your own undead calamities, consider the plots presented on the Zombie Apocalypses table.

entries.caption: Zombie Apocalypses
rows: A twisted wish causes those affected by healing magic and {@item Potion of Healing||potions of healing} to rise as zombies.
Overwhelming magic reanimates zombies again and again as {@creature Swarm of Zombie Limbs|VRGR|swarms of zombie limbs}.
The githyanki unleash {@creature Zombie Plague Spreader|VRGR|zombie plague spreaders} to scour mind flayers from a world.
The seals containing an underground zombie horde fail, releasing ancient {@creature Zombie Clot|VRGR|zombie clots}.

action.name: Spellcasting
entries: The necromancer casts one of the following spells, using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks):
At Will: {@spell dancing lights}, {@spell infestation|XGE}, {@spell toll the dead|XGE}
2/day: {@spell inflict wounds}
1/day: {@spell false life} (as a 3rd-level spell), the goblin gains 16 ({@dice 14 + 1d4}) temporary hit points

action.name: Staff
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage, or 6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands.

bonus.name: Cast Sanctuary (2/day)
entries: The necromancer casts {@spell sanctuary} targeting themself. The necromancer cannot cast another leveled spell on the same turn that they cast {@spell sanctuary}.

trait.name: Nimble Escape
entries: The goblin necromancer can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide} action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: The goblin necromancer wields the {@item Chum-Scraper|NírmunMiscellany}, and can gain hit points if he kills a creature with a leveled necromany spell.

item.name: Invisible Banana Peel of Inevitable Comedy
entries: {@i This humble banana peel is all that remains of a breakfast once eaten by the dread giant Kutal the Hide Collector. Kutal refused to eat anything with the skin still attached, including fruit. Kutal was renowned for whipping his still-living enemies through the air so fiercely that their skin would slough off in one clean piece, which Kutal would keep around his belt. How the banana peel escaped his collection is a mystery.}

As a bonus action, you may whip this banana peel through the air and throw it into a space within 20 ft. of you. As it sails through the air, the banana peel shimmers and becomes {@condition invisible}. Any creature who moves into or out of the space that the banana occupies must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw at disadvantage, or fall {@condition prone}.
The Invisible Banana Peel of Inevitable Comedy can be used 3 times before the magic preserving it fails and it becomes a mundane, but rotten, banana peel.
{@b {@i Curse.}} If the Invisible Banana Peel of Inevitable Comedy does not claim a victim within one round of its use, it will teleport up to 20 ft. to a space it deems more likely to find a victim.

item.name: LF's Locket
entries: {@i This silver locket is inscribed with the following: “LF and GA - steady as the tides.” While the locket is in contact with your flesh, a memory of love protects you from death.}
If you drop to 0 hit points while this locket is touching your skin, instead of making death saving throws you become stable. This has no effect on undead or constructs.
After this effect is used 3 times, the magic of the locket fades.

item.name: Potion of Frogkind
entries: {@i This concoction is dark green and looks like it has some form of water plant growing in the upper half of the flask.}
When you drink this potion, you are {@spell polymorph|PHB|polymorphed} into a frog until the end of your next turn. Use the {@creature frog|MM} stat block.

item.name: Potion of Hard Liquor
entries: {@i This beverage is completely clear, and has a medicinal odor.}

When you drink this potion, you must succeed a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw. On a success, you are unaffected, save for a fuzzy feeling. On a failure, you are {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, you are also {@condition incapacitated} until the start of your next turn, as your body rejects the potion.

item.name: Potion of Vile Bile
entries: {@i This potion is bubbling violently, and the bubbles increase in intensity the more the flask is shaken.}
When you drink this potion, you must spend the next 3 turns vomiting. Vomiting isn't necessarily a bad thing!

Each turn you must use your action to exhale a spray of acid at a target within 30 feet of you. The target must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 3d6} acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

item.name: Dual-Action Hand Crossbow
entries: {@i This hand crossbow has been heavily modified to reduce time spent loading. Two laths (bows) have been attached to a single frame, and the two bowstrings joined to the rotating draw mechanism. The crossbow features a dual trigger, and is loaded via a specialized cartridge that contains 4 bolts.}

Firing the hand crossbow uses the attack action, the crossbow can be fired more than once per turn using extra attack. The dual-action hand crossbow can be fired 4 times before a bonus action is needed to load a new cartridge.

item.name: Cloak of Perpetual Shade
entries: {@i Woven from threads that are soaked in the tragic history of one hundred orphans, this cloak is dark. The hood? Dark. The cape? Dark. The backstory? You guessed it.}
While the hood of this cloak is raised, your face always appears heavily obscured by darkness. Whether this cloak exudes the darkness or manipulates the lights in the area, is a mystery.

{@b {@i Curse. }} The darkness of the cloak goes both ways, and everything you look at is heavily obscured. Unless you have {@sense darkvision} or a similar feature, you are {@condition blinded} while the hood is up.

item.name: Fate-Splitter
entries: {@i This single bladed shortsword is made of a blackened mottled metal. The handle is composed of a length of string wrapped many times around the end to create a sturdy grip. A slim loop of iron serves as a guard.}
Fate-Splitter can hold 4 charges. When the life of a creature is prematurely ended by this blade, it gains 1 charge.

{@b {@i Frayed Edge. (2 charges)}} As an action, you may expend two charges to cast the spell {@spell Bane|phb} without using any other material components or spell slots. This does require concentration.

{@b {@i Splitting the Weave. (4 charges)}} When you use Fate-Splitter as part of an attack on your turn, you may expend four charges to treat one attack roll as an automatic critical hit. You must decide this before making the roll.

item.name: Thread of Spatial Binding
entries: {@i This length of thin silver thread is stronger than it appears, when it is wrapped around a creature not native to the mundane plane, they feel an uncomfortable prickling where it touches their skin.}

If the thread is wrapped around a celestial, elemental, fey, or fiend, the creature is unable to teleport through spells or other abilities. As an action, the creature can make a {@dc 16} strength check to destroy the thread. On a success, the thread is physically broken, loses its magic, and becomes mundane.

item.name: Shard of the Dark Star
entries: {@i This smooth, coin sized marble is embedded into a leather wrap that fits around a humanoid hand, so that the marble is opposite the palm. The marble has a black center obscured by wisps of fog that move over the surface.}

In the presence of sustained bright light, the shard activates and the marble emits a sphere of magical darkness that extends one inch beyond the marble’s radius. Mothfolk utilize these shards to maintain their focus when they venture forth from the Duskleaf forest.
Said to have been hewn from a star that fell to earth, shards of the Dark Star are seen as ill omens, especially by the worshippers of {@deity Solos|Nírmun|NírmunMiscellany}.

item.name: The Wild Mage's Catalyst
entries: {@i This glass syringe is filled with a red, bubbling liquid. A thick iron needle extends from the syringe, and a faint odor of copper is detectable when the syringe is applied. The glass of the syringe is imprinted with “WW.”}

The catalyst can be administered to a willing creature as an action, or to an unwilling creature through an improvised weapon attack against the target’s AC. On a hit, the target is subjected to the poison.

A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 10 (3d6) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The creature also suffers the following effects:

items: The creature’s body is destabilized and able to accept infusions from other creatures

If the creature does not receive a powerful magical healing within 24 hours, the creature’s body will continue to destabilize, adopting new traits and features unchecked until the resulting abomination becomes unsustainable and dies.

item.name: Infusion Syringe
entries: {@i This glass syringe is used to introduce biological material into a creature that has been destabilized by the {@item The Wild Mage's Catalyst|NírmunMiscellany}. A thick iron needle extends from the syringe, and the glass of the syringe is imprinted with the following phrase in elvish: “From this vessel, power flows. From this cup, unto salvation.”}

An infusion can be gathered from or administered to a willing creature as an action, or to an unwilling creature through an improvised weapon attack against the target’s AC. On a hit, the target takes 1 piercing damage and their destabilized body absorbs the infusion.

item.name: Dead Man's Trigger
entries: {@i This slim leather strip has a purple gem that glows in tandem with the wearer’s heartbeat.}

The Dead Man's Trigger stores spells cast into it by the attuner, holding them until the attunement is ended. The trigger can store up to 5 levels worth of spells at a time. The attuner can cast a spell of 1st through 5th level into the trigger by touching it as the spell is cast. The spell has no effect, other than to be stored in the trigger. If the trigger can't hold the spell, the spell is expended without effect. The level of the slot used to cast the spell determines how much space it uses.

When the attunement is ended, any spells stored in the trigger are released. The spells use the spell save DC, spell attack bonus, and spellcasting ability of the attuner. The attuner can use a short rest to end attunement to the trigger without setting it off.

{@b {@i Attunement.}} A creature's attunement to an item ends if the creature no longer satisfies the prerequisites for attunement, if the item has been more than 100 feet away for at least 24 hours, if the creature dies, or if another creature attunes to the item. A creature can also voluntarily end attunement by spending another short rest focused on the item, unless the item is cursed.

item.name: Captain's Sword
entries: {@i This cutlass, pried from the cold dead hands of its previous owner, is perpetually cold to the touch.}
On a hit, this sword deals an extra 1 cold damage.

item.name: Scylla’s Eye
entries: {@i This glass-topped case holds an eyeball the size of a fist. The eye floats in a viscous liquid and sometimes spins on its own to gaze directly at a nearby creature.}

{@i {@b Lightning Redirection. }} The Scylla’s Eye has two charges. While you are holding the Scylla’s Eye and take lightning damage, you can use your reaction to expend a charge and reduce the damage by 1d8. The energy is stored in the Eye, and before the end of your next turn you can release the energy to deal additional lightning damage on a damage roll from a weapon or spell attack. The additional damage is equal to the damage you reduced. The Eye regains all expended charges daily at dawn.

item.name: Chum-Scraper
entries: {@i This staff is carved from a black wood with thorns curving up around a shark’s skull.}

{@i {@b Grim Harvest. }} While holding the Chum-Scraper, once per turn when you kill a creature with a necromancy spell of 1st level or higher, you regain hit points equal to twice the spell's level. You don't gain this benefit for killing constructs or undead.
